title: Victory Mountains
text:
The Victory Mountains () is a major group of <a href="mountain">mountain</a>s in <a href="Victoria%20Land">Victoria Land</a>, <a href="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>, about long and wide, which is bounded primarily by <a href="Mariner%20Glacier">Mariner</a> and <a href="Tucker%20Glacier">Tucker</a> glaciers and the <a href="Ross%20Sea">Ross Sea</a>. The division between these mountains and the <a href="Concord%20Mountains">Concord Mountains</a> (to the NW) is less precise but apparently lies in the vicinity of <a href="Thomson%20Peak">Thomson Peak</a>.
A Ross Sea aspect of the mountains was first obtained by early British expeditions of <a href="James%20Clark%20Ross">Ross</a>, <a href="Carstens%20Borchgrevink">Borchgrevink</a>, <a href="Robert%20Falcon%20Scott">Scott</a> and <a href="Ernest%20Shackleton">Shackleton</a>. The mapping of the interior mountains was largely done from air photos taken by the U.S. Navy and surveys undertaken by <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a> and <a href="United%20States">American</a> parties in the 1950s and 1960s. So named by the <a href="NZGSAE">NZGSAE</a> 1957-58, because of the proximity of this group to the <a href="Admiralty%20Mountains">Admiralty Mountains</a>, and with the intention that many of the topographic features would be named for celebrated victories, especially naval victories.
